sect1.title: Configuring load balancing with &haproxy;
sect1.remark: This is a straightforward explanation how to set up a HA openSUSE 13.1 http load balancer, but not using SLE HA tools, but plain vanilla openSUSE with vi.
sect1.para: The following section gives an overview of the &haproxy; and how to set up on &ha;. The load balancer distributes all requests to its back-end servers. It is configured as active/passive, meaning if one master fails, the slave becomes the master. In such a scenario, the user will not notice any interruption.
In this section, we will use the following setup:

listitem.para: A load balancer, with the IP address &subnetI;.99.
Our servers (usually for Web content) www.&example1com; (IP: &subnetI;.200) and www.&example2com; (IP: &subnetI;.201)

sect1.para: To configure &haproxy;, use the following procedure:

step.para: Create the file /etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg with the following contents:
step.remark: toms 2014-09-17: Not sure about all the options.
step.screen:
global maxconn 256 daemon
defaults log global mode http option httplog option dontlognull retries 3 option redispatch maxconn 2000 timeout connect 5000 timeout client 50s timeout server 50000
frontend LB bind &subnetI;.99:80 reqadd X-Forwarded-Proto:\ http default_backend LB
backend LB mode http stats enable stats hide-version stats uri /stats stats realm Haproxy\ Statistics stats auth haproxy:password balance roundrobin option httpclose option forwardfor cookie LB insert option httpchk GET /robots.txt HTTP/1.0 server web1-srv &subnetI;.200:80 cookie web1-srv check server web2-srv &subnetI;.201:80 cookie web2-srv check

callout.para: Section which contains process-wide and OS-specific options.

listitem.para: Maximum per-process number of concurrent connections.
Recommended mode, &haproxy; runs in the background.

callout.para: Section which sets default parameters for all other sections following its declaration. Some important lines:

listitem.para: Enables or disables session redistribution in case of connection failure.
Enables logging of events and traffic.
Operates in HTTP mode (recommended mode for &haproxy;). In this mode, a request will be analyzed before a connection to any server is performed. Request that are not RFC-compliant will be rejected.
Adds the HTTP X-Forwarded-For header into the request. You need this option if you want to preserve the client's IP address.

callout.para: The maximum time to wait for a connection attempt to a server to succeed.
The maximum time of inactivity on the client side.
The maximum time of inactivity on the server side.
Section which combines front-end and back-end sections in one.

listitem.para: Defines the load balancing algorithm, see .
Enables statistics reporting (by stats enable). The auth option logs statistics with authentication to a specific account.

callout.para: Credentials for HAProxy Statistic report page.
Load balancing will work in a round-robin process.

step.para: Add the following line to &csync;'s configuration file /etc/csync2/csync2.cfg to make sure the &haproxy; configuration file is included:

note.para: The &csync; configuration part assumes that the HA nodes were configured using ha-cluster-bootstrap. For details, see the &instquick;.

step.para: Make sure &haproxy; is disabled on both load balancers (&node1; and &node2;) as it is started by &pace;:

step.screen: &prompt.root;crm configure &prompt.crm;cib new haproxy-config &prompt.crmhp;primitive haproxy systemd:haproxy \ op start timeout=120 interval=0 \ op stop timeout=120 interval=0 \ op monitor timeout=100 interval=5s \ meta target-role=Started &prompt.crmhp;primitive vip IPaddr2 \ params ip=&subnetI;.99 nic=eth0 cidr_netmask=23 broadcast=&subnetI;.255 \ op monitor interval=5s timeout=120 on-fail=restart &prompt.crmhp;group g-haproxy vip haproxy
